Honorable Marco, Honorable Marco, please allow me a minute. Faced with the very serious crisis impacting the automotive sector from America to our continent, Europe stands before a very clear dilemma. Either remain inactive, observe this collapse in demand and the

production, the effects of which cannot even be calculated today, in the name of an abstract coherence for a theoretical model of market liberalism, of total respect for competition, as some voices have also been heard today, or to assume its responsibilities to adequately address the situation.

Furthermore, dear colleagues, the financial crisis has shown us certain interventions by political and economic authorities that have made choices of conduct, of investment of public resources, which until a few months prior were unthinkable.

But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective, reconciling strategy with emergency response, supporting—both through subsidized credit and demand-side support—a selective orientation towards more environmentally sustainable productions.

The agreement reached by the Council and the willingness of the European Parliament send a positive message. One cannot address the extremely serious economic crisis without strategic changes.

For a specific characteristic, today, when discussing European gastronomic culture, we speak of the Mediterranean diet, but certainly not as the sole characteristic of European gastronomic richness.

Mr. President, let us begin with a concept: the Mediterranean diet, as confirmed by numerous studies, supports the fight against obesity and cardiovascular disease and, in general, is highly beneficial for human health in numerous respects.

But here the point is not to insist on imposing the Mediterranean diet throughout the EU or to attempt to favor it over other dietary regimens that are better suited to different climates and regions of the Mediterranean.
However, we have the task of protecting it, defining it in its contents and characteristics, in order to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.
It should therefore be valued, like all other European cultural expressions, which deserve to be defended and promoted globally.

It is a model that the world attempts to emulate. It is therefore important to specify its unique characteristics and safeguard it, to prevent a completely European heritage from being lost in the sea of globalization.

The crisis in the automotive sector has evolved into a crisis for the entire industry, impacting related sectors' supply chains, commercial networks, and consequently, services, presenting dramatic employment prospects.

I believe that even the dramatic decline in these latest enrollments, reportedly for some member countries at -33%, -20%, etc., demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, nor does it originate within the sector itself, or within this or that company, due to managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and, as such, must be addressed urgently and decisively by European institutions.
Some remedies appear to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, with what perspectives of innovation.
It is certainly necessary to support demand. Consumption is the sole engine of recovery.

But while this response, supporting consumption, is being implemented—a medium-term response, I believe—we must state that immediate credit support is needed to resume production, pay for materials, and sustain employment, even in the face of a decline in orders and demand.
Therefore, the credit sphere—but we were saying—it’s important *how*.
And I, too, reiterate here the need for a stronger role for Europe. It is important that European institutions give a clear signal.

America is intervening, some European countries are doing so, and I too hope that my country will move from generic proposals to concrete initiatives, but I trust there will be a stronger European action within the recovery plan and also beyond the recovery plan.

In the next 40 years, we will have to rely on traditional energy resources of which Russia is rich. Can we do otherwise?
I cannot.

This contradicts our own policy of good neighborliness and would not be fair to use even against a small country, let alone against a large country that reasonably demands to be respected.

It is a matter of realism, first and foremost. The European Parliament is preparing, I fear, to approve a document written in the spirit of the Cold War—old, useless, damaging, counterproductive—precisely at the moment when the new American President begins to forge a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot claim any leadership, and I hope the Commission will not adopt these recommendations.

speakers for this energy package, the Shadow Rapporteurs, the Commission Secretariat with all its officials for the collaboration and expertise demonstrated in this dossier.

We can and must all be proud of the result achieved. I am, reflecting on the effort expended when I inherited the directive relating to the internal gas market, with problems of not easily resolvable nature.

I am pleased to have aligned my second term as a Member of the European Parliament with the concluding phase of this package, which I consider to be among the most important files of this legislature in favour of European citizens, our electors.
The Gas Directive, which will come into effect starting in 2011, introduces significant changes within the sector. It is important to highlight as a key outcome the achievement of Option I.
which guarantees the opening of markets and a genuine progression towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.

their particular peculiarity. They are subject to a more favorable regime, demonstrating the attention that the new directive gives to the needs of the European citizen.

particularly in the new Member States, where the creation of new infrastructure would also allow for the resolution of centuries-old dependencies.

Once, we find ourselves in this Assembly to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage originating from a tradition centuries old, a heritage of inestimable value that the world envies, representing enormous wealth for our economy and also for the identity of our Union.
A heritage that today risks facing serious difficulties due to the Commission's and the Council's intention to abolish the Coupage ban for the production of rosé wines, an intention born under strong

pressures and will find its ratification without the possibility of intervention by Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes allowing red wines to be produced simply by blending red and white wines, as is done in countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, under the flimsy pretext of responding to international competition.
As the confirmer of the questioning, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, of significant investments, of passion,

And a focus on meticulous detail is not the response we require, particularly during an economic crisis such as this, when the average consumer is certainly paying more attention to price than to a label’s wording.

To counterbalance this decision, it would suffice to find a name for the new product and inform consumers of the existence of two distinct types of rosé, the differing quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of industry professionals.
Who will pay for all of this?

Does the Commission envisage any support programmes in this regard, or will producers still be required to bear the costs, after having been asked to fight unfair competition from low-cost providers in already extremely difficult times?
I hope that the Council Committee will know how to make the right choice and, if necessary, completely revise this procedure.
Thank you. Mr. President, I would first like to acknowledge the President of the DTP Party, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the distinguished gallery and is following the debate.

Dear Ahmet, please know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize in DTP an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey, and for this reason we firmly condemn the police operations that the
Prime Minister Erdoğan ordered against you, incarcerating all three vice presidents of the DTP along with over 300 militants and supporters.
The victory of the DTP in the latest local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdoğan to initiate direct discussions with the DTP, yet his response has been further repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have, until now, supported the process of Turkey’s accession to the European Union, while simultaneously advocating for the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdoğan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish military, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling with Kurds. Erdoğan himself is closing any prospect of Turkey’s accession.
The responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations, and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion toward Turkey, rests solely with her.

I want to deliver a very strong political message to Erdoğan. Either he makes the pursuit of a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority—and let me be clear, this passes through direct negotiations with the DTP—or we will be the ones to request the suspension of accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path to Turkey’s accession to the Union runs through Diarcavira and through the DTP; otherwise, we—those who have thus far supported the accession process—will be the ones to call for a period of reflection that risks proving definitive.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the Council for sharing their principles and, if I may, Commissioner Barroso with whom I have had a very productive dialogue that has been extremely useful in the work we subsequently brought before the Assembly.

I would also like to express my heartfelt gratitude to the colleagues who contributed to this report, offering ideas and clearly bringing all of their expertise. First and foremost, colleague Demetriu, Baroness Ladford, and the excellent President Depri.
I wish to emphasize that precisely what Demetri, Latford, and Depré state is the most important thing, the challenge of the European Union, because achieving a unified European judicial culture.

Naturally, engaging in a serious debate on what Deprè states – judicial independence, guarantees, and mitigating disparities among the various judicial systems – are the challenges that lie before us.
but I believe the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.

optimism of will and the work that you too, Honorable Romagnoli, have done and the contribution you have given to the report means that all together we can build the European Union and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, it appears that the thousands of deaths so far attributed to asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths so far attributed to asbestos,
of people who risk dying in the coming years due to prior exposure, regardless. The latency period, we know, can reach 15 and even 20 years. They absolutely count for nothing.
It appears that the Eternit trial begun in Turin counts for nothing regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is no family that has not experienced bereavement within its ranks.
Should asbestos have been banned operationally by the Member States by applying Directive 99?

The States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, applying the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and the populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already discussed the Turin trial, in which Swiss and Belgian employers are defendants.
Everyone knew, little was done, and it is primarily industry that avoids its responsibilities, acting within the network of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia can be seen, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, and in Cengio, where deaths are still being counted.
Today, industry is requesting that the Commission tolerate yet another exemption, already granted for a limited period by Regulation REACH in 2006, regarding chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true, they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few facilities, but where industrialists claim the impossibility of any alternative substitute once the plants are closed.

This resolution requests that the Commission address, by 2009, a legislative gap regarding the prohibition of second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts, and other items that should be definitively disposed of.

Only when these are based on the same requests as this resolution, only then can we be understanding.

Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament presided over by you.

I believe that the sacrifices made over the last twenty years within their country and that today allow those twelve countries, previously mentioned in this assembly, to be represented, strengthen Europe.
However, I also want to convey my concern upon hearing her program within her address, which should—and I hope that it will—give strength to this Parliament.
I hope that what he announced to us will come to fruition.

The 550 million citizens who have voted for us in this Europe, who want us and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly attempted to give, but has not fully succeeded in giving.
Regarding this endeavor of his, I invest my hopes and am certain that with him we will achieve the assurances it has offered us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honourable colleagues, it is neither my intention, nor that of my group—which has supported and promoted this debate—to transfer matters of Italian domestic policy to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all; it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counter political and economic influences and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous intertwining of media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, should serve to protect the pluralism of information, avoiding concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to safeguard freedom of information for all European citizens.
Thank you, Mr. President. I am aware that on September 30th last, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indicators in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was voted on, with Marianne Micco as rapporteur, which invited the European Commission and the Member States to protect, I quote verbatim, the multiplicity
regarding opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diverse information channels.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, drafted by Bogert-Quack, concerning the risks of violation within the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which requested the Commission to present a communication on the guarantee of media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to the requests of Parliament.

Please note, Madam Commissioner, that I have not named my country nor my Prime Minister, but in this forum, as a European citizen, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you.

Very important for two reasons. The first is the theme of the research, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the modality of joint programming in research.

Now, we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and the other diseases destined to increase in the face of an aging population.
We request that focus be placed on large-scale, comprehensive studies, directed both toward diagnosis and the identification of treatments.

Fundamental appear to be the investigations into biomarkers, early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the research into curative drugs, and models of care and appropriate services.

to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and thus create a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate results for this type of research.

What are the novelties of the Stockholm Programme compared to those of the AIA? A fair balance between rights and security and legal protection in both criminal and civil fields.
Safety is a right. Not to be attacked in one's workplace, to walk the streets without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence as women, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must guarantee security.
But a security measure that diminishes the guarantees of freedom is an action that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarity.

Europe is the homeland of rights.

A fair balance between the discipline of anticrime repression on the one hand and the daily lives of citizens, their familial, social, economic, work, and study relationships—all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is Europe of the citizen.
and it will be constructed within the Member States and the Community institutions.
European society is more unified, and mobility more intense, than is commonly believed.

Conflicts between states are not impermeable walls; they are networks through which society filters every day.
Stockholm provides its institutional framework: judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, a European justice system, alongside the national one.
and that of the European Union, a European, national, and Community right, a European citizen, a European judge, the national and the Community one.

Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision regarding the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the hopeful smile of the Palestinian representatives.
They were intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on a street in Ebron, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home and occupied, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent located in the garden of what had been her house. The suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built, with European funding, a farm subsequently destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians, too, have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The Council of Europe’s decision marks a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day of the visit, Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to ensure that the voice of democratic Europe is heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we spent in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Thank you, President. The European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist offenses, it is necessary to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are appropriate and effective.

The rights of the defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the institutions of the Union, even when defining lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to certain individuals.

I would like the Commission, from this moment forward, to turn the page and establish relationships of assistance, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition who are in exile, not least Ms. Miriam Raiavi who represents this reality.

I intervene to highlight the severity of the deindustrialization situations affecting various Sicilian industrial hubs, particularly the automotive sector in Termini Imerese, Fiat group, and the petrochemical sector in Gela, Eni group.
The Sicilian citrus industry, damaged by competition arising from low-wage systems within certain EU countries, struggles against Asian competition.
With regard to the processes of severe deindustrialization currently manifesting within widespread areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
to review the actions adopted thus far by the European Commission and to begin establishing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, the theme of fiscal good governance, while always of great importance, has acquired even greater topicality and relevance following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International, G20, and European leaders have discussed it and continue to do so, particularly when addressing tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, a sign of commitment and willpower, but one must not entertain the illusion that an announcement alone is sufficient.
A serious and consistent policy is required.
Many problems remain.
It is truly still too easy to purchase or establish a shell company for tax evasion.
A simple search on the internet is sufficient. There are thousands of websites offering companies for acquisition, even in European Union countries.
and often, an email with a scanned copy of the passport attached is sufficient to open a company.
It is necessary to end the practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation.
This report that I present is based on the communication from the European Commission on fiscal good governance of April 28, 2009.
The report aims to advance concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
It is necessary to consider the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and the illicit flight of capital as a priority for the European Union.
From this derives the principle of good governance, which is founded on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that increasingly greater tax cooperation and collaboration are needed within the European Union.
The overarching objective we must set is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, naturally starting with the European Union.
As the colleague Alvarez has already stated, absolute banking secrecy must be abolished entirely in European Union countries, bringing an end without further delay to the derogation regime.
a temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, instead of information exchange.
I do not wish to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.

I emphasize that we nonetheless require certain points in particular. Broadening the scope of the 2003 Energy Efficiency Directive, combating VAT fraud, and establishing a public register of the European Union.
taking into account individuals or businesses that have created companies or opened accounts in tax havens. Reaffirm and relaunch tax harmonization projects, beginning

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with a single voice internationally, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange on request.

Commissioner Kovac, please also review the other reports. We need a strong commitment from the Commission, and we need to ensure that these priorities are highlighted to the new Commission at the time of the handover.
We will hold the Council and the Commission accountable for the work.
like the European Parliament. I thank my colleagues and, above all, the rapporteurs Ombra for the contribution they have made to this work, which I hope will be approved by Parliament.

I must admit that when we discuss the fight against terrorism, debating solely intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we fail to adequately examine the matter, as if we wished to cure an illness by focusing only on its symptoms and not its causes.
Is it not perhaps time to confront the problem of terrorism, aiming at the heart of the matter rather than limiting oneself to its external phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask and I request of this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism?
Therefore, may this Parliament have the courage to politically address a debate on the level of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on full-face veils, to encourage this Assembly to openly address the issue.
It appears there is no willingness to address the topic.
I ask, and I ask you, honorable colleagues of all political groups, if, not on these topics, on which others should the political war of Europe’s peoples be voiced?

Thank you, President. The closure of negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a feasible objective, and the Švoboda report highlights, in a balanced manner, the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is justice that is the sector in which further decisive reforms are needed.
It is not enough, indeed, to complete the necessary systemic reforms and to enact new laws, and to cooperate as needed with the Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the necessity of creating a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, a central issue, becomes crucial, as does the training, recruitment, and career progression of judges, as well as the absence of any form of governmental influence or pressure exerted upon them.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the necessity of decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiations.

Thank you, President. Croatia’s accession to the European Union reinforces the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating, the specificities of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts to align with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but needs to undertake further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Other steps may be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with what is stipulated in the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.

justice that has severely condemned Italy, which failed to manage waste disposal in Campania. The city of Naples has been subjected to public ridicule for many weeks and many months worldwide.

This debate is not a formality, but aims to be highly concrete, posing clear and precise questions: how many resources, where to obtain them. And I hope, the Parliament hopes, that the answers today and in the subsequent councils on March 12th and 25th will be equally clear and precise.

We wish to state firmly to the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised before the world the banner of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge, today has a duty of consistency, if it does not want to lose credibility.
must do everything possible to ensure these objectives are achieved.

We must be very clear that speaking of a low-emission economy signifies a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system. It means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, European industry, to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligence is ready, the capabilities exist, the will is present; it is now a matter of igniting this engine.
They must do it, the Commissioner said, the Council said. The Member States must do it, the entrepreneurs, the private forces.
but I believe that the essential task of bringing together this complex partnership is that of the European Union.
To constructively address the employment problem, the guiding principles of community relations are three. React, evolve, and protect.

To react, that is, to abandon the celebratory tones of Europropaganda and address in a concrete manner the problems that afflict EU citizens, ensuring a direct connection between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and redefining among young people the perception of manual professions.

To evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market in which flexicurity in contractual arrangements responds to the instability of market demand.

To protect, that is, to provide employment for those who have lost it, first and foremost to our citizens. Member States must therefore evaluate immigration policies based on actual immigration needs. And with 23 million unemployed, consideration should be given to halting extra-EU immigration for a few years.
I see no other ways to protect our work and our social system.
Concrete action, courage, and decentralization are required.

Yes, President, I would like to reiterate once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other parliamentarians and that the majority of the European Parliament has approved, in order to obligate the Council and the Commission to genuinely effective legislation on the matter of corruption.

I have returned on behalf of the Commission for Control on Budgetary Matters from a visit to Greece, and it is certainly the case that one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis also stems from the squandering of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Corruption is corroded by corruption, as emerges in these days, corruption that circulates primarily through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of politics and a segment of entrepreneurs, and white-collar organized crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all of its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States; Member States that do not comply should be sanctioned, and the European institutions responsible for combating corruption and organized crime should be strengthened.
For the masculine and feminine forms, we know well that this difference is even more pronounced in the realm of autonomous activities.
Indeed, women are often compelled to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming a role or shouldering the workload that stems from their dedication to family.

To resolve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures, such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but keeping my gaze fixed on the guiding star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the distressing dilemma of choices between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of familial labor and addressing concrete problems directly through positive and specific support measures for families.
To place the family at the center, otherwise any package of measures will be a disjointed set of interventions, ultimately futile.

Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner. We are gathered today to discuss organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare sector.
but on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems regarding the rights of the donor and the patient that must be addressed on an ethical, social, legal, and economic level.

It concerns activating a virtuous pathway that addresses the serious imbalance between needs and the quantity of available organs, without however compromising the principle of free and voluntary donation, thereby preventing

every form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, guaranteeing the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that effectively balance confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplantation systems adopted in the various Member States, such objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
On this matter, I believe it would be very important to establish a European repository of legal documents and to adopt common standards of quality and security.
We must, however, be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would not only be to narrow our objectives, but also…
Thank you, President. I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work carried out on the European Union’s accession to the Convention on Human Rights.

represents a benefit for European citizens, because thanks to it there will be a new external Tribunal to the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and the Member States.

In virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is fundamental that every nation adhering to the Convention must have a judge to explain the context of each appeal. Similarly, I consider it important

that the European Parliament has an informal body with the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is fundamental that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider developing guidelines with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications the decision will entail.
Thank you, President. 170 measures in 5 years—numbers too ambitious for a program lacking a genuine character, particularly regarding certain issues.

On immigration, the program, beyond the official documents, displays an embarrassing nobility. What is the purpose of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if a political strategy is then lacking?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several fundamental points. Combating irregular immigration along the southern border, sharing responsibility between all European states and the United Nations in countering irregular migration, a policy of agreements with third countries, and above all, the recognition that immigration during times of crisis is not an asset.
From the Parliament's homepage, we read that more than 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the commissioner for internal affairs states that the issue of immigration must be based on solidarity.

We must, instead, reason with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide employment for our citizens. Everything else is sentimental rhetoric that helps neither the integration of immigrants nor, even less, our own people.

The financial realities of these months and years, the new Treaty of Lisbon with its new responsibilities, and the challenge we have set for ourselves with Europe 2020, demand the mobilization of new and substantial financial resources.

And yet we know that if we want to emerge from the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to address the major issues of the environment, the development of cohesion policy and the
in agriculture in the coming years, we have a need to invest more in Europe and in the function of Europe, and therefore in the essential function of Europe, that is, in its budget.

having the strength and ability to develop a discussion and comparison that places the theme of greater resources alongside the theme of greater quality and greater flexibility in their use.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, the European Parliament has called, as we know, to express its final opinion on consumer food information.
It must be stated immediately that this was an objectively laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process, one that could not be shortened.

It concerns, in fact, harmonizing Community law on foodstuffs through regulations designed to make information transparent to consumers, avoiding misleading them into confused or potentially harmful choices, even for their health.

The delegation of the Honorable Sommer, to whom credit must be given for synthesizing multiple needs, therefore aims to remedy contentious and disparate information systems currently in place in the countries of the Union.

It is not coincidental that national regulations to date differ in the denominations of the nature of foods placed on sale, creating a system different from country to country, also fostering unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the European Commission’s proposal, efforts have been made to give new form to existing legislation, involving both the food industries and consumers.
Simultaneously, the report commits the European food industry to providing clarity regarding mandatory indications and the presentation of food and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not refrain from adapting and innovating its food product legislation, in order to better protect food trade, safeguarding it from an increasingly invasive and uncontrolled international competition.

It is no novelty that one hears more frequently about the perversity of food products, concerning refinements and hence nomenclatures indicating aspects that often do not meet food requirements, which are nonetheless marketed as foodstuffs and beneficial for human health.
