Utilizing technologies, the network, and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, and starting not so much from a general framework, but from individual cases, from the specific problems that magistrates and lawyers face.
that are new and that must stimulate a professional growth for these legal operators within a stimulus that is, in fact, acceptable to them.
contribute to the reflection on their lived experiences, on what they have learned to respond positively to the challenges Europe presents.

As you can see, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new to the tradition of courses that have been conducted until now and which we find scarcely effective for this purpose.

We need to know how many funds are available and which, to express a doubt about the idea as it was written in the communication of a central European institution that governs this process, because we are for a bottom-up movement and not instead a centralization.
This is a new configuration.

What we want to convey, however, is that if a European mindset is not fostered among magistrates and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and the citizens who request it, we will not make Europe.
Therefore, this is not only an important document for European justice, but an important document for the entire development of European unity.
Thank you, Mr. President. The proposal regarding the rights of bus passengers aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on passenger rights for bus travel and should guarantee passengers, as already occurs in the rail and air sectors.
The position in the second reading aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I concur with the speaker Cancian’s line of reasoning, whom I thank for the excellent work performed, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passenger rights in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the matter of information regarding passenger rights. It would indeed be helpful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transportation. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services via bus and those via rail.

Regarding individuals with disabilities and those with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee the utmost protection, and I would propose a timeframe of 24 hours instead of 48 to request assistance, as well as greater safeguards for compensation and replacement of the devices that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, considering the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barrier should be eliminated and existing infrastructure improved to ensure accessibility.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.

Thank you, President. I thank the rapporteur, Mr. Sterks, who has done an excellent job on this report, which addresses how to extend free circulation in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I concur with the rapporteur on the purpose of this directive, namely to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

Indeed, to have a borderless European maritime space, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate in a satisfactory manner, but also that the various simplification systems are applied simultaneously.

This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to ensure that sea freight transport becomes more attractive and is used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures among Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will revitalize maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be activated as quickly as possible, as this would enable a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is important for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, initiating information exchange via email is not entirely efficient and proves futile if the information systems are not interoperable from a technical standpoint.
Regarding language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more expedited, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I wanted to offer particular congratulations to our speaker, Hon. Kramer, because we all know that we have achieved a result that at times seemed unexpected.
I would like to recall that this dossier was indeed considered a dossier at risk of conciliation proceedings.
Therefore, we have also heard from the Commissioner’s words, it is evident to all that we are facing a complex undertaking that has required considerable time.
Consider, for example, a 1996 directive that this work leads us to the fifth and most important amendment of the Industrial Emissions Directive.
These few data points alone, I believe, reveal all the shortcomings and even the defects of this legislation.

I would like to recall that this is a directive of difficult implementation, with nine member states affected by infringement proceedings and an area of application so extensive as to be, at times, even inappropriate.

All of this—we must not conceal it—has entailed significant efforts, has required sacrifices from all institutions involved, from all political groups, from all national delegations, and has frequently presented us with truly difficult choices.

However, I am here tonight to state with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results in protecting competition, the environment, European industrial and employment policy.
We genuinely have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

I genuinely hope that the results of this restructuring will, in the immediate term, include a reduction in administrative burdens and, in the medium term, an improvement in environmental performance and a strengthening of European industry.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to emphasize the situation in which the Church places us before a reality to which, for too long, due importance has not been attributed.

That is to say, the instability in Central Asia, which is unfortunately growing, while hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

The Kirchner has suffered in the last month from extremely harsh clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatreds which will make the country's stabilization even more difficult than it was previously.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been stated, is to assist Kikisda as much as possible under three aspects. Through immediate aid for the
supply of emergency aid for the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Second, through long-term economic assistance, as far as the European Union is concerned, within the framework of the

strategy for the central area and the instruments implemented within that context, through political support to underpin the process of returning to constitutional legality and the realization of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, held even amidst crisis on June 28th, can be considered a first step on the path back to a constitutional order, under obviously very difficult conditions.

The electoral process of June 28th, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which naturally took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Cristia will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential one.
This may allow for a better consideration of the country’s diverse ethnic composition and the need to garner consensus from the various components of a nation so fragmented and composite.
The European Union and Crisa are linked by a partnership and cooperation agreement that provides for regular meetings of a Parliamentary Commission for Cooperation.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations may resume as soon as possible with the participation of a Parliament that is democratically elected, the Chiso.
In the immediate term, what is crucial—as already stated—requires stability and our political-economic support. Let us avoid being parsimonious in both.
A European Council that no one voted for. Today, we also have a rotating presidency in the hands of a government no longer trusted by its own citizens.
This alone would suffice to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that has become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite who do not recognize the citizens.
The Belgian non-presidency programme addresses structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability, and competitiveness, with the EU 2020 strategy as the chosen instrument.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe towards entirely different ingredients than those that led to the failure.

A general reassessment is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather a death certificate for the European social model that europopaganda would instead like to administer as a cure.
Today, Europe is a vast edifice collapsing in on itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary. More decentralization, less bureaucracy, more practicality and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inexorably accelerate the decline.
Mr. President, thank you, I apologize. I would like to emphasize in this intervention how the progressive erosion of income for European farmers at the expense of increasing
profit margins within the agrifood supply chain are generating a concerning economic marginalization of those employed in the agricultural sector, resulting in the abandonment of these activities.
Therefore, a change of course is required, a shift that the European Commission itself recognizes and that the report before the Chamber this morning,
approval by the House this morning, to which I wish to express my support, highlights with extensive justifications and suggestions, including legislative and sectoral ones.
It is indeed necessary to combat global commodity speculation and guarantee supply security.

Furthermore, greater price transparency must be ensured, which will not only render justice and dignity to farmers but will also correct the significant imbalances currently existing in terms of bargaining power and abusive debts among the various stakeholders.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and gain influence within the mercantile context of the European Union.
Mobilism and myopia: this is the diagnosis of the malaise afflicting Europe 27 today.

Stagnation, because if one in four young people in Italy is unemployed and 16 million are counted as unemployed in the Eurozone, it is also because, amidst the Europropaganda of recent months, no genuinely effective action has followed.

Myopia, because in charting a path out of the crisis, Europe not only reprised the usual prescription, but completely lost sight of the most genuinely territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, drawing sustenance from those natural energies that each geographic area expresses: districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and artisanal crafts.

To resolve the employment problem, one must first think on a smaller scale, invest in local entities, and prioritize subsidiarity, safeguarding a heritage comprised of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the compass of European policy does not guide it toward the territory, the failure of the Europroject is a certainty.
Thank you, President. In the construction of a Europe of rights, a central place is occupied by freedom of information, pluralism of information, and independence of information.
The Commissioner, both male and female, have observed that there is a country within the European Union—a founding member, moreover, under the Treaty of Rome—where there is
the pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the press.
What democratic electoral competition is possible in a country where a Prime Minister and a political party control the media?
What democracy can exist in a country where a law is being pushed through in a matter of days that prevents journalists from publishing judicial news?
Forget Watergate, forget the Guardian’s stenography, forget lapdogs. What kind of democratic country is it where the internet is sought to be brought under control?
What democratic country is one where those who stand against the prevailing consensus are marginalized, and freedom of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bokassa, nor the Romania of Ceaușescu, nor the Italy of Berlusconi, where this unfortunately also occurs because the European Commission lacks the courage to assert an autonomous and independent position vis-à-vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is a significant step, but would be…

It would be appropriate for the Commission to conduct an impact assessment, as some colleagues preceding me have recalled, of the postal market opening, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in areas difficult to reach, such as mountainous or rural zones, to receive mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure that this occurs?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be exploited to justify the issue of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they all have the tools to do so.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. Today's debate on readmission agreements cannot sidestep the increasingly thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one aspect of the agreement is focused on countering irregular immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us little about it, despite the Treaty of Lisbon requiring the Commission itself to inform Parliament promptly.
Libya, as is well known, has not ratified the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it, to date, demonstrated conduct consistent with international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants, held in an inhuman manner in the Libyan Brak detention center, or still to the closure of UNHCR offices. But I think especially of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic patrol boat opened fire.

against an Italian fishing vessel from the Navy of Mazara del Vallo present in international waters, with the justification of the presence of undocumented migrants on board. A most serious justification that leads us to believe that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy which

It also provides for the rejection of immigrants to Libya without provisions relating to the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examinations of each situation. It also contains the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Given that, in this case as well, part of the agreement is confidential, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of its content. If it does not deem it necessary, in this specific instance, to request clarification, the matter...
to the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on vessels if there is suspicion that they are transporting irregular migrants, because if that were the case among the provisions

Economically, it is advantageous for Europe to deepen trade relations with rapidly growing neighboring countries. However, the EU has consistently, at least in principle, pursued a trade policy toward third countries, taking into account social and humanitarian considerations.
We must therefore assert these clauses with firm resolve towards Turkey, a country that is re-Islamizing, in which the condition of women is progressively deteriorating, with over 1,500 women.
Women killed in 2009 in domestic violence cases. A country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamist extremists. It is enough to recall the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to assume a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned with the leadership role that Turkey is seeking to carve out for itself in the Arab world and the

The friendship Turkey is cultivating with Iran and groups like Hamas. In any case, if trade policy must be, let it be. But this must never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, this measure seeks to strengthen and rationalize the European Union’s pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives set forth by the amendments to the Regulations 726 and Directive 2183.
Thanks to intensive and efficient coordination between the Council and the European Parliament, and the parliamentary committees responsible for the matter, it has been possible
to discuss today a proposal aimed at improving the community pharmacovigilance system and refining the substantial and decades-long activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on harmonized standards throughout Europe.

Reference is made, therefore, to a wide range of interventions that span from a more precise definition of roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders, to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to which

it recognizes a fundamental actor role in the system for strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, in simplifying communication, registration, and assessment activities of alleged negative adverse effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also through closer collaboration at the European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will indeed ensure a productive exchange of information concerning drug adverse reactions.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information to benefit patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.
Thank you, Mr. President. Just these past few days, meetings have taken place here in Brussels.

Many representatives from municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems affecting the lives of our cities, the old and new needs impacting workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has struck our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that cohesion policy has, on many occasions, been the only concrete tool available to territories to attempt to provide responses.
Therefore, we can state that cohesion policy has, in recent years, served as an essential lever for the European integration process for all regions.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the period after 2013. We are therefore at a turning point.
Therefore, it is vital to avoid certain risks.

The first fundamental is that of its own renationalization.
It would be a serious step backward.

Then it is necessary to ensure, in the construction of the financing plan, adequate provision both for the needs of the most vulnerable entities and, simultaneously, for the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have demonstrated efficiency and to make the ability to sanction more compelling for those who have not.
We expect the Commission to move in that direction.
Honorable colleagues, the road to a woman-centered Europe is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak clearly. The global crisis has impacted the labor market, severely testing female employment, which in 2008 decreased further by 0.7 percentage points.

Despite the provocations on the subject of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a waning Europropaganda, no concrete measures have yet been adopted to guarantee women genuine fulfillment both as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not simply periodically change its label.

Thus, the harmonization of maternity leave across Europe by the Institute is commendable, but inefficient is the choice to address, within the same report, the complementary and equally important matter of paternity leave at its margins.

Greater integration of women is not solely a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
Thank you, I’ll begin again. Thank you, Mr. President. The rapporteur for the Development Committee, Hon. Mitchell, has requested that I substitute for him because he is unable to be present today.

I thank you for the work performed, with your customary punctuality, and for the quality of your proposals, which have garnered the favorable, I would say unanimous, opinions of the Development Committee.
For what I will say, but especially for what my colleague Michel has done to date, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a substantial majority.
But I will now turn to the discussion.
During 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905/2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
Proposal accepted by us.
But the Cooperation and Development Regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission is required to allocate funding, it must follow comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine this proposed funding and, should the Commission exceed its remit, Parliament may adopt resolutions to request the Commission to alter the decisions in question.

Only since 2006 to the present day has Parliament considered that, in at least 12 cases, the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its decision proposal.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Commission proposed applying the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in strategic financing decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
Indeed, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain, well-defined cases, the Parliament may delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions. But what might these decisions be?
In our view, the selection of countries to which the European Union should provide development assistance

It is a choice that rests with the legislature. And then, which sectors should be prioritized in funding? Education? Healthcare? Environmental protection? Good governance? The development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the areas, the subjects in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislature must provide the executive with precise guidance.
And it is precisely this direction in which, I believe, the requests of European citizens ultimately converge.
I genuinely hope for the greatest possible consensus on this report by Mr. Mitchell.
to the speaker on policy

The integrated maritime situation requires moving beyond a phase of good intentions and providing new impetus to a strategy that will serve as a catalyst for growth and development of the European Union, bridging the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, in the fight against climate change, and against pollution.
This very morning, our colleague Pirillo called the Parliament's attention to yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate concrete action, operating not only with governance tools, but implementing specific legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past errors, attributable to an approach often too sectoral.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and demanding crossing that cannot tolerate lapses in attention and requires adequate investments and

mechanisms of participatory governance, both at the inter-institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out for the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It is for this fundamental reason that understanding the management of the Mediterranean basin as a shared heritage of all riparian states is essential, based on the principle of the

Alternatively, the increasingly common practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to being inconsistent with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the concept of effective and shared governance.

I recall, in this regard, that only a month ago this interpretation by Libya resulted in a veritable armed assault against a European fishing vessel, and it would be erroneous to maintain that this is solely an Italo-Libyan matter.

Thank you, Mr. President. I thank Hon. Meissner for the report on integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sphere.
Therefore, cooperation between small and large ports facing the same maritime basin should be encouraged, facilitating a more fluid exchange of commerce.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and inland port infrastructure, particularly that of ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another theme, namely that of port security.

It is necessary that there be a standardization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and to prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, instead, in order to ensure greater safety, must incur higher costs.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thirty years ago, Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people. Today, it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet, in Western Sahara, there are deaths and injuries among a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in its own land.
Morocco has effectively closed its borders to anyone who might witness these events.
No information and no representatives.
Access was denied by a French parliamentarian and our colleague Meyer.
Europe stands by passively.
There is no indication of communication from the Commission that renders us subordinate to the mediation of the UN, which continues to fail as it has for the last thirty years.
There is no statement from Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
It is necessary to react with a parliamentary resolution.
It is necessary to react toward Morocco by halting every initiative regarding trade agreements, beginning with the renewal of fishing agreements.

Thank you, Mr. President. My contribution does not aim to be the usual rhetorical-skeptical exercise, but an impetus that begins to pay more attention to content than to form, and abandons propaganda in favor of concrete action.
Having failed the Lisbon Strategy, Europe adopted the EU 2020 slogan, but in reality, it offered no innovative responses to employment issues.

The data confirms it. 9.6 is the unemployment rate in Europe, 20.2 the youth rate. In Italy, the third net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9 young people without employment.

In the Europe I envision, there are no wasted resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments to ensure that training programs prepare professionals for sectors within the internal market, where tangible employment opportunities exist.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our territories.
The world of crafts offers a unique employment potential and a body of knowledge, to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, and Madam President of the Council. The European will to establish ambitious goals in view of the next conference on climate change is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

International preparatory negotiations for the Cancun conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to register appreciable progress toward a global agreement, but have confirmed distrust and resistance regarding the commitments undertaken in Copenhagen.
It has already been cited, but I would like to cite China here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase of 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
and perhaps not even, but a compensation attempt solely through a 100% reduction of European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal of an unconditional 30% reduction, to which we strongly object, illusory, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a potentially significant increase in global emissions by that date.

Here, in this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least reckless and even demagogic to hypothesize figures and sketch suggestive but unrealistic scenarios where unknowns inevitably reflect on the dimension of costs.

The hope is that the European Union will bring to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because an agreement that yields concrete and perceptible results is always and in any case preferable to

expectations inevitably destined to fail and to render increasingly unbelievable in the eyes of public and international opinion—this, indeed, would be damage difficult to repair—the efforts of governments on major environmental issues.

Thank you, Mr. President. I have but one regret in this chamber tonight: that we are discussing the Sahrawi people solely because the Moroccans have invaded the Tendopoli outside and the IUN. And this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have independently developed the will to discuss this matter, which has been festering for 30 years on international tables.
This is the most relevant political datum.
We have been compelled by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to secure human rights.
Why, what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there must be a referendum there for self-determination?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is a strong component of the relationship, that we must demand forcefully and with all consequent actions that there be a will no longer postponable.
We must strive to build the conditions so that the Minusma mission, President, is not alone in building the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must strive to use all the means at the European Union’s disposal to influence this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to 30 years of a people’s suffering.
Mr. President, beyond this matter, I wished to raise a point with the Presidency.
I believe that someone still does not fully understand what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am compelled to raise a fundamental issue here. Commissioner Callas for Transport repeatedly refuses to meet with the board of Sky and Space to discuss Project Cesar, which concerns everyone from an economic, environmental, and security perspective.

I invite the Presidency to summon Commissioner Callas to the chamber and to explain what program they intend to pursue in this sector, which is both delicate and important for the European Parliament.

The report and discussion certainly contain positive elements. The general orientation is toward the simplification of procedures and the streamlining of bureaucratic steps for third-country workers with a regular residence permit in a Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe, tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to structural deficiencies in the European production system and as a consequence of a crisis that does not seem to be ending.

Even before considering the situation of third-country nationals residing in our countries, it is imperative that Europe commits, above all, to implementing economic, political, and social measures that help our citizens to find or regain employment.
If Europe is able to provide employment for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations for adequately accommodating migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, above all, to make Europe grow on its own feet and with its own strength.
Our countries will then possess the strength
Thank you, President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for specific categories of citizens of third countries.
Not all individuals benefit from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals residing legally within Member States and for beneficiaries of refugee status or of international protection, as defined by Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to avoid a growing demand, for example, for seasonal personnel simply because they are paid less or because they have different, lower, costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same work.

It is necessary to avoid, for example, the risk that many multinational corporations relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is more economical.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment for European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, those posted, refugees, and self-employed workers be included in this directive.
Making distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, human trafficking is now the second most lucrative source of profit for organized crime globally, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against illegality, against the crime that breeds crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of these proportions, Europe must justly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.

In combating this phenomenon, cooperation between member states and police authorities is necessary, but above all, the certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, let us remember that many people are discovered.

They are exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair, and are prepared to do anything to leave their land for the promise of a better life, a promise that will ultimately fail to materialize.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit more fully and with greater care to ensuring that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their countries of origin.
acceptable. Let us help them in their own homes. It must be the guiding principle of European political action because our efforts must be directed not only to repression, but also to prevention.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Lady Aston, honourable colleagues. As Vice-President of the Development Committee, I am involved with the issues affecting many countries, particularly in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where, in addition to the customary institutional meetings, I made a point of meeting with representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visiting some of the centers where they work.
I must say that they work very well too. I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to
to repeatedly commit mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, particularly against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it has been a very recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I wish to make is directed towards the general necessity of a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly strengthen the funding allocated to the initiative for the protection of women and against other forms of violence.
like other forms of mutilation, these too constitute a severe violation of human rights and the physical integrity of women.
Thank you, President. The European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that encompasses the majority of UNESCO sites and which is part of a major economy.
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban, and culturally significant sites that have played an important role in the history, culture, and integration of the European Union.
The approval of a trademark is an important step in the process of European Union cohesion and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be observed how this choice bodes well for future generations, who will increasingly possess a shared vision of European heritage that can historically and culturally enrich them.

I must thank the rapporteur for her efforts and extend my sincerest congratulations for the negotiations conducted with the Commission, ensuring the effective success of this initiative, so important for the future of territorial preservation.
Mr. President, honored colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease among them, represent a public health priority for the European Union.
The illness in question has heavy consequences not only for health but also for those who suffer it.
but elevated indeed are the costs that must be sustained for direct care and for informal care.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, does not only affect those who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for the patients themselves.

Therefore, a European response to the problem is necessary, a global coordination among Member States, a synergy of concerted actions primarily concerning the scientific and research fields, and one that assumes responsibility for the project.

enhancement of prevention, diagnosis, and refinement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among States regarding the results achieved within incremental citizen-level initiatives to improve disease knowledge.

Thank you, President. The situation is that Campania, particularly the city of Naples, unfortunately lives—night after night—in the eyes of the world, and the European Union has had to address the issue on several occasions.

Faced with such a situation, now paradoxical, akin to that of a developing nation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law, and what economic sanctions will eventually be applied to Italy should the waste crisis in the countryside fail to find a definitive solution in the near future.

I also request that the Commission provide detailed data regarding European funds that have been managed to date by the Campania Region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, normally when we speak of emergency, we speak of dramatic, extreme situations that nevertheless find a resolution within reasonable timeframes.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, evidently something is not functioning correctly.

The Italian government in recent years has sought to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal. But evidently, if today the streets of Naples are overrun with tons of refuse,
tons of garbage, the blame is primarily attributable to local authorities, municipalities, and their total inability or unwillingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear, and absolutely beyond any doubt, that the conditions in which Naples and the Campania region find themselves are due to the inaction that has characterized, for so many years, municipalities, provinces, and regions in the management of the waste cycle.
If due diligence is not given to waste sorting, the first indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian Government has had to send in the army—this happened a few weeks ago, but on other occasions previously—to replace hundreds of municipal workers suddenly and simultaneously afflicted with illness, it clearly cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has struck Naples, while the rest of Italy experiences matters quite differently—for example, in my region, the Veneto, where the collection of sorted waste has been ongoing for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate—it means that responsibility for the emergency lies.

on Campania’s politics and local administrators, and above all, on the pervasive collusion with organized crime, which has consistently sought and obtained immense profits from the waste management business, thanks to the Camorra’s infiltration of politics and local government.
Following the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem was resolved, it is beneficial that the European Union
to block funds to Italy until a sustainable waste management cycle is presented, one based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which once again relies on uncontrolled landfills such as those of Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Parco Nazionale del Vesuvio, nor of incinerators that produce death, tumors, or a genuine public health emergency.

Public funds in Campania, during the environmental emergency of these 13 years, have solidified criminal relationships between politicians – both left- and right-leaning – entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

And in environmental matters, solutions are pursued through the criminalization of dissent, the criminalization of local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done, utilizing misleading information to suppress those who defend nature and the land.

and there is also a no to the criminalization of local communities’ dissent, therefore a yes to legality.

the report to which we expressed our support defined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, took into consideration

Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one with millions of people demanding a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, and protesting against corruption.

President, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean have, with this measure, initiated a phase even more compelling than the actions we have taken.

The work carried out by colleague Rivellini, which has been widely shared, I believe merits a formal acknowledgement in this setting.

particularly regarding the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a question. On this occasion, the Parliament aligns itself with the Commission.

Mr. President, Commissioner, in my opinion we have two problems. One concerns method, and the other concerns the substance of this matter.

The methodological point is that we are proceeding through an artifice, for which we thank Honorable Fraga, namely the oral question, to discuss something that, after the Rispona Treaty, should instead be a right of this Parliament.
I believe that this practice must end. We cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Co-decision making is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are holding this debate; it will conclude, the treaty will proceed, and we will say yes or no in the end.
Indeed, this method needs to be reconceptualized.

Regarding this matter, however, I simply wished to emphasize, while agreeing with many of my colleagues’ points, the measurement of the effects of fishing agreements, to ensure they are not merely commercial agreements through which we purchase cephalopods at one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability but, above all, the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many employed individuals are affected, understand what rate of innovation exists for artisanal fishing, understand the utilization of these resources.
not merely a straightforward commercial exchange, but a fisheries agreement with all its implications.
President, the favorable vote cast for the action of the Honorable Rivasi is the result of an evaluation of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
which is 2009-2010, and aims to establish general conduct criteria applicable in any future global health emergencies.
The report, following a lengthy and positive phase of revision, establishes cooperation, independence, and transparency as its principal pillars.

It advocates for greater and improved cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and the European institutions, so as to develop a harmonized and proportionate risk management approach.
The objectives are the mutation of the strategy of the Member States concerning the national influenza preparedness and response plan, including vaccine stockpiles, the publication of names, of
all experts consulted by European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media tasked with disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Thank you, Mr. President. To date, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been provisionally incorporated into Community legislation through annual fishing possibilities regulations.
These concern conservation, management, exploitation, control, and marketing measures for fishery products and farmed aquatic resources in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of such a recommendation, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for its incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question through a single legislative act to which future recommendations may be added.
Today, we have accomplished this, and it will improve legal certainty while simultaneously representing an important step toward simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obligated to ensure full implementation of agreed-upon measures as of the period of high stability.
Timely transposition was therefore necessary to render those measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at the Community level and to ensure legal certainty in the matter.

Mr. President, I believe the approval of the report by my colleague Podima represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, and stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European sphere.

It is now evident to all the urgency of equipping ourselves, as Europe, as a coordination among the 27 countries, with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy and not merely being subjected to it.
For this reason, the proposal to tax financial transactions has garnered considerable resonance, extensive discussion, and significant attention.
The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this provision is an important and significant development, because for the first time, it did not hesitate but instead took a step forward.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue along this path.
I voted favorably on the reports concerning gender equality and female poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that they were discussed today, which marks the centenary of International Women’s Day.

Despite Directive 2002-73, concerning equal opportunities for men and women in access to employment, vocational training and professional advancement and in working conditions, further efforts must still be made to achieve proper implementation.

Consider, for instance, that despite a significant increase in female education levels in recent years and the fact that the number of female graduates now surpasses that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors, often with lower pay, and occupy fewer leadership positions across all spheres of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependents—such as children, people with disabilities, and the elderly—and to adequate parental leave and flexible work arrangements, prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, encouraging women to demonstrate without the yellow.
I thank all the colleagues who participated; finally, we return to discussion, and I hope we return to action soon, with concrete choices regarding common economic and industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lang report and the excellent work done by the colleague, and to the communication of President Tajani.

manufacturing sector, to the most advanced sectors and to even traditional ones, because there lies a frontier that can still be tackled and was not so obvious until recently.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not determined in the finance or service sectors, but here still. It is not too late for us to aim for a challenge for Europe, to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

Thirdly, it has been stated that the new industrial policy focuses on factors, rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and instruments that can genuinely promote new enterprises, new resilience, and updating.

Therefore, I believe it is important to emphasize, as has been done, these new factors on which action must be taken. Credit; we urge new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner regarding credit. Raw materials, energy costs, and immobility.

innovation, research, the necessity of strengthening in Europe the capacity to transfer the results of research and innovation within enterprises, into new products, and into new methods and organization of production.

We must leverage a very particular fabric within our Europe, and in certain countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of businesses, the quality of products, in short, the distinctiveness of industry in Europe.
and I believe that we should rediscover them, let's say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, in order to innovate and transform them.

European policies succeed when they intersect with and find a territory capable of addressing them.
Therefore, thanks to Lange, and we foster an excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a timely manner.

Today, the urgency pertains to women of other cultures living in Europe and throughout the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to assert minimal standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this holiday without placing the issue of women in the Arab-Muslim world at the center of our attention; otherwise, we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon will also concern us.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that grow year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow.

Therefore, I have been asking for some time, and I ask again today, that Europe implement targeted policies against the proliferation of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We, women and men of Europe, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only that, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamist intellectualism.

Thank you, Mr. President. I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform that occurred on September 12th has been unanimously recognized as a significant step taken by Turkey toward Europe.
Naturally, many steps remain to be taken, and in this regard, I express concern over the numerous arrests of journalists.

I emphasize that Turkey is the European Union’s seventh commercial partner, that the European Union is Turkey’s primary commercial partner, and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has fostered mutual understanding and peaceful coexistence between peoples.

I therefore applaud the notable progress on the front of promoting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those through the motorways of the sea crossing the northern Adriatic and the northern Tyrrhenian Sea.

Mr. President, with today's vote, we have given further impetus to the definitive resolution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

Indeed, I wish to recall that the over 300 amendments presented in the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which serve to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as its objectives.

Lampedusa has been overrun by tens of thousands of North Africans whom the island could never, ever accommodate.

And if we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of people fleeing will continue.
The clandestine migrants who have arrived in recent months must be returned home. There is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been cooperatively absent, exhibiting shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer endure.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only assist Italy in the repatriation of undocumented migrants, but must also support the Italian government’s efforts to prevent further departures, particularly from Tunisia, of thousands and thousands of people.

Quite a different matter applies instead to Libyan refugees, regarding whom Europe must stand alongside Italy in the operation of identification and logistical management, but above all must commit to ensuring that the refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The welcoming of those fleeing war cannot burden Italy alone.
It is time to stop talking.
The European Union, if it exists, should make its presence felt.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with undocumented migrants, while France repels them with shameful methods.
Irregular migrants must be returned to their countries of origin, while all Member States must commit from now on to receiving Libyan refugees.

While Europe feigns ignorance, the Europol 2011 report on organized crime states that with the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen, powerful criminal organizations – Turkish, Russian, and Albanian – will be able to expand their operations across Europe.

Thank you, President. Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater relevance, and the
Attention has focused on the integration between economic and environmental policy, and on the inclusion of environmental issues within policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusion, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, suitable for providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this draft regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data, environmental statistics, and other statistical sectors.

Thank you, Mr. President. My favorable vote on the Garriga report regarding the forthcoming financial prospects of the Union stems from the conviction that precisely during one of the most critical periods,

Regarding what is termed the European spirit, it is decisive to insist and prevail upon the indispensability of providing credible instruments, starting with an adequate financial endowment for the Union.

Therefore, the request for a 5% increase in the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to provide answers to the major issues before us. Indeed, these resources are needed for

to tackle real problems, such as stronger cohesion between the Regions, greater research and innovation capacity, a more robust ability to generate growth and offer employment. Indeed, without resources

adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer. Beginning with the introduction of this intermediate category into cohesion policy, which makes sense only if it does not cause damage to the existing categories.
That is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council follow the recommendations of this report.

Thank you, President. The new Hungarian Constitution reduces the scope for intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive branch, thereby challenging the customary balance of powers.
Social rights are being hollowed out; the State provides assistance to the needy only if they accept to perform work of public utility.
The right to self-defense is ultimately enshrined, permitting the possession of firearms at home even without a license.
Abortion rights are prohibited, and rules strongly discriminatory towards homosexuals are introduced.
All of this is contrary to Directive No. 78-2000, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are scarcely compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Honorable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategically significant document that provides a solid framework for the negotiations on the financial perspectives post-2013.

beginning with the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.

it tells us that cohesion is today a vital hub of the European project, an important asset for all, to be safeguarded, protected, and renewed.

of cohesion in Europe and also to substantiate the cohesion policy with that more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to guarantee for Europe in the coming years.

risk and speculation. When one arrives, as has happened, at exchanging, at insuring 400 million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, one understands what risks we are running.

Having said this, however, I would also like to mention two issues. The first issue is the relationship with the Council. The second issue is the cohesiveness of the proposed reform of financial markets that we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I state it very clearly. The feeling is too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting swiftly and effectively on the financial markets reform front.
I hope that the new Presidency will take on this problem, because even on this occasion, we must put in
I anticipate a lengthening of timelines largely attributable to the positions, difficulties, and contrasts that arise during Council meetings.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second question, the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure concerning OTCs, there is also the measure concerning short selling and other matters.

I wish to highlight two points. The specific issue of the commodity market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of local authorities' exposure in derivatives within the European Union member states.
I believe that these are issues on which Parliament must intervene.
Thank you, Mr. President. The Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences with the release into the sea of radioactive water 6,500 times exceeding legal limits.
The risk of food products being contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370,000 tonnes of canned tuna. Our primary suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information regarding the place of origin.
Today, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and intends to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into force before two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not have effect before three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your address gives us good hope. The hope is that the Polish presidency will be a contribution to the fight against the Europe of national egoisms.
national, without looking to the future, which could be a contribution in favor of a Europe that truly considers itself an integrated reality with a common destiny.
But, as you rightly pointed out in your presentation, a Presidency has concrete problems to address and resolve.
I wish to indicate to you, in this brief time, two crucial issues concerning the economic and financial crisis.
First issue. The reform of financial markets.

It is not a technical problem; it is a major democratic issue of our time. The timelines are too long. We must resolve matters such as those concerning the reform of short selling and OTC transactions.
Second point. We are faced with the issue of financial transaction taxation. We need to delve into the specifics. We expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen Agreements.
No one doubts the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

Therefore, all Member States must commit to reviewing the operating mechanisms of Schengen, ensuring that freedom of movement does not compromise the legitimate need for security on the part of our citizens.

As far as we know thus far, the Commission’s orientations may also be partly agreeable, particularly regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows Member States to temporarily provide border controls in cases of emergency.
However, it is necessary to see how this will occur and whether actions will follow the statements, and above all, concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to revise the general reform of the European border protection system, particularly external borders, on which Frontex must as soon as possible become an agency with genuine powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish to merely survive.

The crisis has profoundly marked the lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering social and cultural quality, well-being, and the future of young people and Europeans.

beyond values of cohesion and prosperity. Emerging from the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, to which, if necessary, we must also curtail excesses, by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies

Against recession, remedies against a development model that has placed the person a step below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that today are its due.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources—even new ones—to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, with research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure, and employment. Because without work, people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervance, Beressa, and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
to European leaders. If they exist, now it falls to their responsibility to implement them.

But Europe will not be credible with its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent. And we here want to be consistent in this Parliament and at this stage of Europe's life.

Therefore, if we say we are founding the union on values, on human rights, I don’t believe we can abruptly halt or drastically cut a program for those who are hungry, for those who do not have the right to food, access to food, family rights.

fundamental for an unresolved legal matter. It is agricultural land, it is social land, and if it is to be social, Commissioner, let it not be at the expense of other social programs, but rather a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
Let us say we want to guarantee food safety for Europeans, but the primary right to safety is to have it, food, and then for it to be healthy.
So, here it is: our consistency and our commitment.

Let us therefore posit a legal solution that ensures continuity and, with the assistance of non-governmental volunteer organizations, guarantees the primary fundamental human right, that to safe drinking water.
Solely to support this argument and highlight two aspects in particular. One because it fits within the debate currently underway on…
review of the common fisheries policy and the underlying option, which concerns the regionalization of a policy that, over these years, has demonstrated its weaknesses through centralization.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in colleague Iotova’s report describe a particular situation, but one that could also be replicated elsewhere in Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea within the Kingdom is not dissimilar.

In the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Mediterranean? That is, the interactions, particularly between European and extra-European fishing, let’s say, are interactions that are often very detrimental to European markets and European consumers.
The second matter I would like to briefly highlight is that of reference to a common coast guard.
There is no politics if there is no exercise of control.

Today, controls are carried out by disparate forces across Europe. I believe the time has come to understand how one of the first European law enforcement agencies, namely the coast guard, could benefit from common management, greater coordination, and, why not, a single European body.
Thus, with this hope, I fully support the contents of the report presented by my colleague Iotova.

Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activity of offshore oil platforms.
The European Parliament, with this report, also wished to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
for sector operators and aims to establish high safety standards designed to fatigue their driving of the European Union in the promotion of offshore activity safety.
The new interventions in the field requested from the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
in the sector, at the procedural and liability level, the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk diverting attention from achieving concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, beyond increasing the accountability of operating companies, requires improvements to communication and information and knowledge sharing mechanisms and advocates for strengthening and expanding the role of the European Maritime Safety Agency’s expertise.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the enrichment of this text to which we have expressed our support.
I thank colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, and I also thank Commissioner Edegard.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning in order to genuinely seek a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been noted thus far, have primarily focused on reducing CO2 emissions.
The proposal highlights how we must also address the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause tropospheric ozone formation, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been recalled that I believe it is right to keep firmly in mind. Today, we are able to do so with absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies at our disposal, and although it is doubtful that CO2 emissions are the primary factor.

And although it is undeniable that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are quantitatively in much smaller percentages, it is undeniable that their potential is very high and that, therefore, we can truly achieve significant and very important results within a few years, within a few decades.
