There are signals, it was also recalled in the United States by the Commissioner; I saw a study that was published in Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce, with which I find

there are many points of contact with respect to the analysis conducted by our colleagues, and I imagine these too will be things that will allow Europe to present itself to Urban with an even stronger, more concrete, and more important position.

I simply conclude by recalling, as has already been recalled, that for this extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are experiencing, we have been discussing the homeless population until just moments ago, there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore, considering this great sensitivity

Sensitivity, of course, should be our top priority, and regarding employment, we should be able to also conduct a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what we concretely intend to do in the direction of development, their well-being, and the protection of jobs. Thank you.

The single market, the free movement of goods, and the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements that have intervened independently of a modification to our legislative approach, to the European approach, and to the national approach.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments derived from these occasions. In particular, a genuine phase of simplification of the legislative system must be initiated. A phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and individual states.

I would begin precisely with our documents. I take this opportunity to suggest a sort of clarity test on our documents. When we produce a white paper, a green paper, it must all be more comprehensible. And I go so far as to say that the true, and perhaps strategic, proposal for our Europe, and to truly initiate this…

May this virtuous phase of legislative initiation be characterized by assigning a specific delegation to a European Commissioner tasked specifically with clarifying legislation and the relationships between the Member States and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Commissioner, first and foremost, I too would like to positively acknowledge, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission last June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon, and combating it requires measures of a European scale.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How to redress their grievance?

In many Member States, the political will to combat corruption has been lacking. Consider, for example, that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens’ rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it adopted to date by Member States are insufficient to contain a phenomenon in expansion.

It is the European Union that must provide a unitary and robust response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on the lives of people, on the stability of social security and welfare systems, and on the capacity of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its Member States that
they could be utilized to provide essential services, instruction, childcare, employment, transportation—in short, to divert clean resources to support individuals.

Therefore, it is necessary to demonstrate greater courage and resolve, both in monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and in intensifying and strengthening measures to combat corruption at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt, at the very least, minimum standards for defining the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the package recently approved.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the scope of the phenomenon in Member States, essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of contact points combating corruption, as I proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not recent; it has existed for several years.
Has the time perhaps arrived to undertake a critical assessment of the policies followed thus far? Has everything invariably been done well?
We have always conducted appropriate analyses of the situation.
Has the correct approach been chosen?
The very European Central Bank that, as Minister Rostovski says, saved Europe, has also always done well when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates.
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of policy. But is this the only problem?

Certainly, if one considers that we are still at the implementation stage of July 21st, this should at least suggest better preparation and organization of the summits and their conclusions. But politics will always be slower than the markets.
Then the point is to look further ahead, shift the emphasis to the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso’s address, there was more concrete detail on the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission must move beyond its weakness, stating that the priority is combating unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth, and a strategy of public investment, also changing the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its primary standing.
a world-renowned tourist destination while also being able to enhance, in terms of both environmental protection and competitive capacity, its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and far from straightforward undertaking, even considering not only the opportunities but also the assertiveness of other countries in this sector, of other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, within this framework, the Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the Commission that we approved in the Regional Development Committee,
to maintain a robust overarching strategy for the entire European Union regarding tourism, while also emphasizing the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, full engagement is essential from the outset, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity of the Regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It also seems to me appropriate to propose identifying a European mark that is capable of defining a high quality of the tourist product.
Naturally, it will be for the Commission to better define the priorities, particularly from a financial perspective, to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.

President, the preparation of a common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities facing European development and the European economy.

It is, in fact, a matter of acting on the lever that can genuinely trigger a moment of growth and also of new, qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to new opportunities in innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation that particularly emerges from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that leads to practical application, that reaches
to give rise to new enterprises, which lead to new patents and which do not remain purely basic research, purely knowledge—important, yes, but not sufficient to truly trigger a wave of development.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial planning and for fostering dialogue between research institutions, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Thank you, President. European Schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one's mother tongue for the children of agents of the European institutions who are required to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg as far back as 1953 on the initiative of a group of civil servants.
Over the years, considering the positive nature of this teaching method, 14 European schools have been established within the various member states.

While acknowledging that the European Schools system represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European School, such a system may present obsolete aspects and must, in some way, be adjusted and adapted to the new economic and social needs of Europe.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by colleague Cavada, which envisions greater involvement of the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States, called upon to work towards developing and improving the European Schools system.
And invest, as we know, investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you, President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In recent decades, the number of natural disasters has increased exponentially, causing the deaths of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work of the report on the European Union's capacity to respond to disasters, in which it is
how much remained to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the increasing frequency of earthquakes, floods, and tsunamis.
The European Union’s response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of the existing instruments and procedures.

Although Member States and Community institutions have acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis has raised a series of problems concerning efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

Precisely for this reason, I expressed a favorable vote for the text of my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which envisions greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management, increased coordination.
Among the parties involved, it represents a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlap and time wastage that would hinder the provision of rapid and effective assistance.
Yes, it is merely a worthwhile initiative. I believe it will involve constructing, instead, a European policy regarding tourism.
The European brand has a good insight, but on two issues I want to dwell. There is no tourism of the sea or the coastline without a policy of coastal planning.

I believe that the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the conception of the sea and the conception of the coasts are not limited to a form of urban planning that ends at the high-water mark but comprehensively involves the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, as we will need to build everything that underpins the claims of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no longer work, where it is important instead to prevent further depopulation and ensure human settlement.

Well, it's not enough simply to make claims there; rather, one should suggest to Europe and individual states that they intervene regarding the tax base. Tourism in rural areas might mean paying lower taxes. Perhaps in this way a genuine opportunity can truly be built for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
Thank you, Mr. President. I wish to express my congratulations for the work carried out by the honorable colleague, which logically fits within the framework of the actions.
Initiatives and actions undertaken at the Community level in the field of tourism, following the assignment of new competencies to the EU for the tourism sector by the Treaty of Lisbon.
I share and wish to emphasize the assertion of the importance of a Europe destined for a certified and quality tourism, and the will to promote this path.

the same idea by translating it into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, and coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the Union's countries.

An approach to be valued and rewarded, given the sector in question with its implications in terms of the percentage of fil produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Enterprises, with attention to the protection and enhancement of the environment, are configured to develop and therefore to respond to the principal challenges posed by contemporary issues.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Thank you, President, also for the recovery efforts. Three brief observations. More Europe is needed here as well.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain matters there will be a genuine attitude in which not only is it hoped for, but more Europe is actively built.
More Europe means, for example, genuinely beginning to consider a common highway patrol, identical regulations from the perspective of protection and safety.
More Europe means having a European training policy, not simply delegating this to individual states, but building a genuine training policy, for example.
With regard to schools, with regard to young people, and with regard to categories that are somewhat more at risk—I mentioned motorcyclists a moment ago, but we can also speak of truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within vehicles that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-dependence devices.
I believe it is a targeted strategy to build with automotive companies and European vehicle production.
Well, I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I genuinely think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Thank you, President. This report addresses a topic that is global food security. Global means that this topic is not solely about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the issue of food supply concerns all communities, even those in the most developed nations.

among some lines as that essential element of coherence between European policies and this objective of global food security because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often inconsistent in its choices.
I simply want to outline some other titles—three lines of innovative work—that I believe we should develop further.
Firstly, food procurement today is jeopardized by price volatility stemming from speculation on food commodities, which must be contained if not prevented, derivatives, etc.

Secondly, the theme of land grabbing—the appropriation of land—which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty, of negotiation, because democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples, is at risk.
third, the coherence between procurement and energy policies
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the world’s peoples.

a purely political character, because I believe it is necessary to bring this major issue of food security back to the center of the entire European Union's initiative.

It is not merely and solely a matter of assisting developing countries in addressing this issue more effectively. But the food crisis, considering that demand is projected to increase by over 70% by 2050.

agricultural products. It is a significant issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the primary threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with its Member States, make every necessary effort, beginning with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this significant issue.
Greetings to the Commission. I must genuinely thank all those who have contributed over these weeks, these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the Assembly.
We have worked, I must say, very well, and a truly constructive debate has developed.
The resolution we are therefore voting on today is the result of a truly collaborative effort and the fruit of the contribution of all political forces and the entire Parliament.
I believe a common and very strong sensitivity has developed regarding this topic, partly because, we must remember, we live in an era truly characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we consider them in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled. If we consider that in 1975
78 catastrophic events had been recorded, whereas we are now experiencing nearly 400 calamitous events per year.

In the last 20 years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered 90,000 or more, and over 29 million individuals have been affected by disasters, while economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from our side.
We all have the images of the Haiti earthquake, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan in our minds.
Europe itself experiences flash floods, fires, and we recall the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano, every year on its own territory.
There is no need to look further to affirm how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental principles that serve as our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are proceeding along these lines.
The European Union’s intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as I believe the work of our Commissioner Georgieva attests, but today we need to take a qualitative leap.
A step up that we are ready to take to move from an ad hoc response to one instead where the reaction…
be strengthened through the proactive identification of resources already available in Member States and made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to emphasize that for this leap in quality and to transition from information sharing and emergency response to the role of planning, monitoring,

We envision a coordination that highlights the fundamental role of services such as GMS, and I take this opportunity to express the concern regarding the budget allocated to these new technologies, which are essential.
We have emphasized the importance of communication with citizens, because the Japanese experience has also taught us this—it is never sufficient, it is never adequate.
and we await from the Commission, to which we request that it present the proposal concerning civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to conceal their faith, priests barbarically killed without authorities lifting a finger. Anti-Western foreign policy – this is Turkey today.
My party, the Lega Nord, has always opposed Turkey’s accession to Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today, more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring the accession negotiations to a close.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must receive an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what it must do.
Cyprus is a Member State, fully entitled to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by any means against the arrogance and political and military assertiveness of Turkey.
Let us immediately halt negotiations for accession and remain ready to suspend commercial relations as well.
President, we are living through a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, of the entire European construction.
Having this awareness would mean escaping a myopic logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will for budgetary austerity.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order; we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without a judicious investment policy capable of reinvigorating the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear result in this scenario is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the most vulnerable segments of society.
Therefore, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, we continue in a single direction, that of rigor without growth, a direction that has proven to be incorrect thus far.
The colleague Ferrera’s work on this report is highly valued.
Indeed, of the six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, this is the only one on which I and my group have expressed a positive vote.

We did so because a clause protecting social rights was also included, starting from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of Parliament’s role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while not being able to alter the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward, and moreover establishes a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into consideration.

And so, in this context, while maintaining that, in our judgment, a vision based solely on an austerity policy does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive note against the trend.

Honorable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands raised the matter at the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to guarantee effective border controls and are afflicted by pervasive corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
Thus, populist movements are not defined in this way, but rather the airport in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

Should Bulgaria enter the Schengen Area at this time, law enforcement and security agencies anticipate that Bulgarian borders, particularly maritime borders, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become a hub for human trafficking and drug smuggling.

It is natural that some Member States have significant reservations regarding Bulgaria and Romania’s actual capacity to ensure effective controls at the borders against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore entirely natural that they have opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is intense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons for opposition are numerous, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore request information regarding the intentions of the Commission and the Council with respect to this delicate matter, which, in my opinion, has been treated thus far with
and without considering the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and give the go-ahead only when there is reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions for the security of European citizens.

Thank you, President. The crisis in Europe is entangling the problems of public finances and private capital with those of productivity within our businesses in a vicious circle. And the spectre of recession is present.
Therefore, if the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission to ensure, together with Parliament, that our good principles are put into
and that legislative initiatives from the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice for Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Consider, Commissioner, what it would be if all Member States anticipated the application of the directive against late payments? What a great advantage it would be for SMEs? Then, SME evidence is important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Certainly, it is right to verify whether when we legislate, we do so truly in the interest of and tailored to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we request that this process proceed with great constancy and tenacity—let's say, in depth in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
If we appreciate what is also being done by the Commission, we are ready, with the budget and with other possibilities at our disposal, to support it.
I will say only one word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say this to you, Commissioner, because we must help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Thank you, thank you Mr. President. I have expressed my favorable vote for the text presented by the Honorable Member Wallis.
Without prejudice to the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also undergo considerable online development for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through a joint activity with Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens’ trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the report concerning the provisions for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility regime, to which we have expressed our favourable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

concretized, on the one hand, by avoiding the setting of unrealistic and impossible-to-satisfy requirements, and on the other hand, by establishing a so-called flexibility regime which articulates itself in the provision of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative limits of

permitted emissions, anticipates the market issuance of a predetermined annual quota of tractors meeting specific characteristics and thereby allows for the time-diluted adaptation to stipulated standards without causing disruption to the relevant productive and industrial sectors.

The Honourable Tantarella, the work accomplished has been significant; she has demonstrated a careful balancing act between the requirements dictated by the major challenges facing the European Union at this time and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Thank you, President. The current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade imbalances between countries, financial markets lacking common regulation, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently highlights the need for informed citizenship, with rules and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a system of global governance, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies. And decision-making bodies, international economic organizations, must be the principal actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, specifically, needs a transparent brake to reduce exacerbated instabilities, also stemming from globalization, and to guarantee sweeping reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment, and this resolution underscores it for all countries.

Thank you, President. I have cast my vote in favour of the report by my colleague, Honourable Matera, which analyses the situation of Single Mothers, who today represent, as has already been stated, more than 5% of the European Union’s population.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the evidence presented today supports policies that can represent concrete assistance for these women, such as, I know, the facilitation for the
healthcare assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for work-life balance, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment benefits.
Only through the adoption of these measures can one respond to the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, President. The budget sets forth few clear and important objectives within the scope of the EU 2020 strategy. For this, a thank you to the rapporteurs.
It is essential to focus on investments and not merely on prudent balance sheet management.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for engagement.

I commend the commitments undertaken regarding pilot projects and preparatory actions in rubric 2, as well as the funding of the integrated maritime policy, which should not come at the expense of other initiatives and programs in the fisheries sector.

This will allow us to implement new policies for the improved management of marine resources through comprehensive research and data exchange regarding fish stocks, imposing new projects that can be utilized as best practices in other marine areas within the Adriatic region.

I conclude with a small postscript, within the scope of future discussions concerning the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and, in particular, regarding the fisheries fund. I hope that greater effort will be directed towards controlling fishing activities, the core of the fight against illegal fishing, but also the foundation for rebuilding the relevant instruments.
that fish be considered a common resource.
Thank you, Mr. President. The economic, financial, and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most representative and alarming indicators of the current situation is the near 6 million jobs lost in the last three years, data that are destined to increase as this situation persists if a swift and effective response is not forthcoming.

The colleague Bastos’s text emphasizes that concrete progress requires enhanced energy, synergy between education, training, and the labor market, and a united political will aimed at ensuring greater alignment between demand and supply within that market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I have cast my favorable vote.
I cast my vote in favor of what was presented by Hon. Angelilli because it addresses a problem that, as a mother and as a grandmother, deeply concerns me.

Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse, and the abhorrent world of child pornography means defending our sons and daughters, and our grandchildren, consequently defending the most vulnerable.
Increased prevention, stricter criminal action against those who commit such offenses, and more careful protection of children—these are the core points of the document voted on today.
Undoubtedly, the path is difficult.

I am particularly thinking of the spread of child pornography material via the internet, which can only be combatted with close collaboration between member states, law enforcement authorities, and internet service providers. Thank you.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report by Senator Fidina, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, necessitate prioritizing the citizen in their capacity as a consumer.

center of community debate and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain merely a principle enshrined at the treaty level, but must be a concrete guiding principle for the policies of the European Union.

A protected and informed consumer, made more aware and therefore capable of fully utilizing the tools and resources at their disposal, capable of fully exercising their rights, must be the ultimate objective of the European Union's new strategy for consumer policy.

Thank you, thank you, President. The phosphates present in detergents for household washing machines end up in European water systems, rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of various life forms. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus presence in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algal growth depletes oxygen for other living organisms, can also produce toxins destroying fish and plant species, and thus reduces the quality of the water itself.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text voted on today, because it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent in order to purify Europe’s water resources.

Mr. President, the European Union has produced a vast quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the Stockholm Programme.
There is a disjunction between this corpus, this legislative monument, and its utilization by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of the individual States have grown within the law of their own country and possess primarily training in that regard.
While we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes their mindset and imbues themselves with the knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before discussing training, it is necessary to address a broad communication to citizens and legal professionals so that they become advocates for this significant development and foster the desire to utilize the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a movement that must be created from the ground up within in-service training. One cannot conduct lessons as if addressing schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults who are professionally very accomplished.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity when dealing with one's cases, connecting with other colleagues, and finding solutions, since today Common Law and Civil Law converge; they are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the crucial point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, in our Convention we request a shift in direction, a bottom-up approach, more focused on legal studies than judicial training.

There exists an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting; it is a network of officers in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage the magistrates in this regard.
Here, the core of our project lies in this; we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

The plight of the millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the supplementary assistance offered by the European Fund for Growth and Employment. Data collected reveal that most beneficiaries of the Fund are unable to find new employment, while the luckier ones are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, sometimes lasting only six months.
In many cases, it is the unemployed who forgo this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution; it does not merely plug the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and with excessive lightness by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose genuine competition constitutes the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe ceases to promote economic self-harm, defending a short-sighted stance toward global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.

However, this is not enough. In a challenging moment such as the present one, both economically and in terms of employment, communication, new technologies, and innovation are a primary asset that Europe must defend with greater courage.
Each European citizen must be able to circulate freely among the Member States, benefiting from the telephone tariff established by their national operator.

Enough fraud and exorbitant bills for those who travel within the EU. If we genuinely want to provide citizens with concrete support, let us therefore create a kind of Schengen for telecommunications, which no longer imposes different rates on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Thank you, President. Colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that visited Sicily last November.

Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wistrom, has written a letter to the Italian minister, the Minister of the Interior and Chancellor, and has received a response that provided us with fairly clear answers.

I want to remember, above all, the fact that after that visit to Italy the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but the situation itself also changed in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated.
However, this should not deter us from the necessity of a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that remains current today is Lampedusa's status as an unsafe port, and the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrade in Briacola following the fire of
September 2011, which damaged it but only partially, that is, a dormitory destroyed, one damaged out of seven buildings in the facility, and then the de facto suppression of the project.

Now, aside from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was Tripoli during the time of Gaddafi, and I don’t find this analogy flattering, given that migratory flows, even if considerably reduced in number, even for seasonal reasons,

They certainly haven’t stopped. It is important that a first aid and reception activity functions, and functions in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other shore after journeys that were neither easy nor free of risks. And that is well known to the Somali shipwreck survivors who have arrived in Italy.
Thank you all.

And the Turistico Residenzio Cala Creta, where guests are currently accommodated, is neither a CIE nor a CARA and, above all, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa in the meantime.
Everything is entrusted to the good will and good heart of the carabinieri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to make is that of the function the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

To have allowed thousands upon thousands of people to accumulate in a location that, by capacity and by its intended function, could only accommodate a few hundred, and people who had never had the opportunity to be in such a large space, contrary to every legal and ethical norm.

passage, having allowed a territory of just a few square kilometers, already challenging due to its location and logistical difficulties, to be compelled to accommodate a number of people exceeding its own inhabitants, must do the
to reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension that subsequently escalated
to the fire itself.
I believe that colleague Rinaldi’s excellent presentation was successful in the chamber.
I wholeheartedly concur with the favorable assessment of the report.
Despite this, I would like to raise a small point. Our Europe, in relation to this new world seeking to find democracy and different economic conditions, is an Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to devote, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to the economic transactions that occur in the Mediterranean.
Medrano, a fishing place
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe that will set very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules there.
And so why not utilize fisheries agreements, providing support to these countries so that those countries apply the same rules that are applied in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fishing, beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this fracture is increasingly less fractured, but rather increasingly a homogenous place upon which to build the future of Europe and of this new world.

Expected under the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional actor in the field of security policies and consequently has the right to participate actively and decisively in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union’s security model.

Colleague Borsellino’s report identifies the five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and advocates for increased judicial and police cooperation among member states to counter organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools for guaranteeing a European space of freedom, security, and justice.
President, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law.

While emphasizing the importance of mutual recognition and the harmonization of rules protecting the presumption of innocence, it is important to underscore how the law must be of utmost clarity and easily comprehensible, so as to make clear to everyone which action constitutes or does not constitute a crime.
This is particularly true for directives that must be equivalent to national law.
Any lack of clarity may, in fact, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a consistent, high-quality European strategy in criminal law matters.
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union safeguards the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses.
I have no doubt that those consumers who are most vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health issues, or simply a lack of sufficient information, must be protected with greater care.
I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the proposal by colleague Perez because I concur that the creation of a strategy for consumer law
the so-called most vulnerable, contributes not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a single market that is safer, fairer, and more competitive.
Yes, Mr. President, the report by my colleague Perez, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, concerns the need to consider the development of a

a strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in anticipation of the strategy that the European Commission and Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
Consumer vulnerabilities arise from various factors and may potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to develop a targeted strategy for this purpose, one that, by considering the composite nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static definitions is rigid and unable to consider all facets of the issue and the diverse possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other, it averts the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protection measures.

Thank you, thank you, President. The management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history since the 1990s and is, to this day, probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite significant investments in control measures having led to greater compliance with regulations, misgivings regarding the issue of overfishing still persist.
I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva-Irueda report, which proposes a reduction in the permissible catch rate, greater control, and a strengthening of measures for capacity reduction.
Relations between the European Union and China clearly demonstrate imbalances at the commercial level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to assist European businesses in overcoming the crisis and to ensure more equitable access to international markets.
I have therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing in particular among the issues highlighted by the rapporteur the application of the principle of reciprocity to relations.
relations between the European Union and China to enable fair competition on international markets and the request for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Thank you, President. The road is still long, but today's development could be an important step toward the introduction and application of a financial transaction tax.
I understand the prudence, the caution, the need for gradualness expressed by Commissioner Scemeta, and the technical problems rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament expresses a clear political will, with a substantial majority, to provide impetus and drive to the initiatives necessary to address the issues that remain open, particularly at the Council level.
We all want to carefully evaluate the impact of this tax, but it is not fair to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic behind the proposed exemptions.
If one is attentive to reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the broadest possible tax base, with a low rate, and not seek to extend exemptions indefinitely.
To those concerned about the effects on small investors, I would remind them of the progressive nature of the tax, whereby those who conduct more transactions and more
transactions, and it is clear that the relevant authorities will in any case need to monitor to ensure that customers and end-users are not made to bear any potential costs.
Therefore, I hope that Parliament will pass a vote with a large majority in favor of this tax.

Thank you, Mr. President. Since 1990, through the instrument of macroeconomic assistance, the European Union provides economic aid to countries facing short-term balance of payments difficulties, in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both.
The rather lengthy timelines, coupled with the difficulties demonstrated by the decision-making criteria used to date, have made it necessary to formulate some amendments to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulations, which aims to make assessment criteria faster and more effective, and to establish clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Thank you, President. There are approximately 100 million European citizens engaged in various volunteer activities.

From major sporting events to cultural happenings, the role played by volunteers is fundamental, and the work of those who rush to provide assistance and solidarity in the event of severe natural or environmental disasters must not be overlooked.
Volunteering represents one of the most extensive expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I anticipate the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of currently existing obstacles.
Thank you, President. From the communications sector to finance, transport, and energy, from culture to healthcare, the role played by technology is increasingly relevant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital media makes cybersecurity a priority on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed foster economic and social development only if existing regulations guarantee user security regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.

Therefore, only full international cooperation involving states, members, institutions, and industry stakeholders can give rise to a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Thank you, Madam President, thank you to the Commissioner, for saying such important, entirely agreeable things.
I find it truly, as he said, striking that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from colleague Oconi.
But it is equally evident that this scandal has truly highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the existing European legislation on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed thus far in this Chamber, which has so well represented the Commissioner, and therefore I would not wish to dwell on this aspect in the limited time available to him.
I believe it is wise to deploy everything necessary so that we can offer the best possible service to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be a catalyst for taking a further step forward. I refer to what the colleague mentioned earlier.

The communication provided to patients is truly inadequate; only the positive aspects are invariably emphasized. There’s talk of a kind of eternal youth, of promised beauty, when no prosthesis is entirely without risk.

I believe that this awareness, especially when discussing purely cosmetic surgery, must truly be communicated to people, to young women, because we know that there are very young individuals approaching these types of procedures.
Therefore, I see that you are absent with conviction, so I implore you, let’s truly work; the deadlines are tight, we should have already completed it yesterday.

Thank you, President. The Council’s regulation concerning the multi-annual plan for ring net fisheries was adopted prior to the entry into force of the Treaty, and consequently, an alignment has become necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the Treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could impact the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason, it is often my vote in favor. Thank you, President.
Thank you, thank you, President. From Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, numerous environmental disasters have struck Europe in recent years, endangering the health of European citizens.

The colleague Ader’s text concerns the revision of Service Directive 2, which aims to contain the effects of incidents involving significant quantities of hazardous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into effect starting in June 2015, are intended to protect the environment and, above all, to limit tragic consequences for the health of citizens. And for this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote.
Thank you, Mr. President. I too thank Stevenson for the excellent work and the framework he has given to this report, which substantially addresses the two main issues.

This is not merely a plan for managing herring; it is fundamentally about ensuring a future for fishermen in some respects and planning within the marine environment to ensure that it, over a multi-year period, has its protections.
But the key point of this report remains the matter of delegated acts.

I believe the Council must accept the framework established by the Treaty of Lisbon, and I also think that the time has come for the Parliament, in some way with a perhaps more authoritative voice than that of the
A debate within the Fisheries Committee or a debate on a report concerning king scallops must have the courage to take a very clear and strong position with regard to the issue of delegated acts.
We assert the right that in these matters there genuinely be the ordinary procedure.

So perfectly that the issue also encompasses, in addition to numerous other fishing sectors – which will, moreover, worsen relative to the ongoing reform – matters pertaining to agriculture and other themes.
The essential element is the respect for the will of Parliament.
In the preparation of this report, no consideration whatsoever was given to the directly affected parties, the trucking companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport occurs by road.
Their rights will be disregarded if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we are committed daily to reducing the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like these nullify those efforts.
all our efforts, because they will stifle the companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with devastating economic losses, and with new forms of unfair competition.

Very little would have been needed to achieve a balanced account that did not overlook the crime of survival faced by our companies during a very difficult economic period. But such a dialogue proved impossible.

Conversely, the report deliberately disregarded even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive. It even overlooked documents from the European Commission, in which the hazardous nature of practices like retrofitting was acknowledged – practices which are, however, reintroduced in this report.
Colleagues, the document we will vote on tomorrow will ask you to disregard the positive achievements made in recent years, and European businesses will once again bear the costs.

Just to say, Mr. President, that Acta was a very serious political error. Let's set aside the legal aspects. It determined a reaction in the world of immense proportions, and that alone is enough to say that it is a political error.
Why benches?
Why did it create the suspicion that access to the web would genuinely be closed off, which is a major modern revolution?
And why is this?
why did he make the mistake of conflating counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena?
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.

And then another error that excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been carrying out for some time, which is the creation of a new copyright, a new author's right. Now, this, while some would like to preserve the

The old copyright law that existed before the web. The point is that we need to work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, reject it, and exclude it, because it is an impediment to our work.

Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measures—orphan works and the forthcoming one on copyright management societies—before the ecological Parliament.
This is the advantage. But let's work on this by thinking with our brains and not just with emotion, but without having our hands tied.
Thank you, Mr. President, simply to add my voice to the praise this report has received in the Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the European Union's capacity.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce, and manufacture within the framework of our conception of an inclusive economy, socially and environmentally sustainable.

Therefore, I believe that some of the guidelines here within this measure are very useful, others could be added, and I believe it is important to gather this guidance, working ever more so that attractiveness is the…
as a consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness initiatives that position the territory itself as the proponent of a productive, industrial vocation,

Manufacturing services that, originating from the territory, are respectful of all environmental compatibilities. And alongside European policies that move in this direction, a voice – from the territory and from Europe – that is attractive for investments and for growth.

Thank you, President. When discussing sensitive topics such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic production, we are discussing the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is indeed important to respond to consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is equally important to ensure adequate application of Community legislation by authorities, bodies, and interested operators.
For this reason, I express my favorable vote for the colleague’s text.
The history of the initial comments on the Council has now entered a phase of reductive reading, and this is incorrect because significant progress has been made.
Consider, for example, the severance of destructive links between banks and public debt, and the employment plan, however weak.

It appears that the spirit of revitalization and a renewed path of political unity is returning to European institutions, after so much slowness and torpor, and a willingness to achieve real progress toward greater integration.
and we have recorded on this a strong unity between Parliament and Commission.

I do not speak of victors and vanquished, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality in contrast to the previous diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis, of community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not in order to create new exclusionary axes, but to build a common and respectful consensus among all member states.
This is the path to the political objective of unity, without which every banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be entirely inadequate.
In June, with the Council’s decision to return to Member States the possibility of reinstating border controls, a new Europe was born—an Europe courageous in fulfilling the desire of
greater security of its citizens, inspired finally by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, redirected towards the defense of the rights of its peoples first and foremost.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional incident, but rather respect for the will of the citizens, and not for that Eurocracy which for years has feigned a lack of understanding of what is truly happening outside the glass palace.
No fictitious influx of undocumented migrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in irregular migrants, measured by Frontex, of 35% in 2011.

I regret only that the scenes of political maneuvering played out in the previous plenary session have stolen time from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning why it was not us, but the Member States, who were defending the interests of our citizens.

If Parliament fails to find its own identity and the courage to challenge the sentimentality, the sterile platitudes upon which it has long navigated, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr. President, I wish to draw this Assembly’s attention to the fact that yesterday was
It has been officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and definitively identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others is their existence, and this occurred on European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents an utopia and wants to realize it. And it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind child who lacks eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African man who lacks legs can run in the Olympic Games in a speed competition.
Indeed, Europe must be the home of science. This momentous event that will open new frontiers to knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Thank you, President. Too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not file reports due to fear or a lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today seeks to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice in all cases.
All countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance is the recognition of victim status not only for individuals who have suffered harm as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased resulting from the crime.
On September 11th, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
One million people have requested the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On October 15th, last Monday, the British Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum for Scottish independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks thousands of people have signed petitions to hold a referendum on the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, Lombardy, and throughout all the regions of northern Italy, hundreds and thousands of people signed petitions requesting greater autonomy from Rome.
But even in the Basque Country, amidst the strong winds, citizens are vocally demanding autonomy and independence from nation-states.
And what does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Quadras, even worse, has invoked the use of force against the Catalan citizens.
Their statements constitute a most serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy which we preach here and which we must defend.
I tell them that the people will write the future of the new Europe, not the Brussels bureaucrat.
The path is already laid out.
The austerity policy adopted to emerge from the economic crisis has not yielded the hoped-for results.
as highlighted in the report by colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget aimed at
Sustaining growth and employment will be possible by rebalancing the economies of the Member States, thereby improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore cast my favorable vote.
Thank you, President. The social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making fiscal adjustments to their respective national budgets to consolidate public finances, the European Union is, in some cases, perceived as an entity that exacerbates the financial burden on taxpayers.

Therefore, to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more tangible investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the programmatic document of an institution. From the budget, one understands what it is, what it does, and above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We stand before a crucial choice: between a budget of survival, of mere existence, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, in innovation, in young people—that is, in the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

All should understand that, as colleague Calfin clearly stated among others, Europe can today do what states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for territories—where social cohesion is either strengthened or the lives of citizens, of whom we have spoken, are undermined.
Major European decisions risk being stifled today by accounting disputes within the Council, but not only that, among beneficiary, payer, and paying countries.

We say it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on what has happened in the past, that contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various categories.

The war of positions has begun: statements, declarations of position by certain states that view the budget as just another expenditure item, one that can be reduced without remorse, indeed perhaps useful to bolster an easy-to-provoke anti-European sentiment in times of economic crisis.
It is a flawed position that does not facilitate the integration we are seeking to achieve in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as we have said so many times.
We adopted a stability pact, which was also intended to be one of development, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Here, we at least seize the opportunity of this budget, this multi-year framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Thank you, President. The lack of information and awareness of one’s rights, compounded by obstacles

Language difficulties and the failure to recognize diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems encountered by citizens of the Union when residing, studying, or working in another country of the European Union.
Unfortunately, there remains a lack of visibility regarding the concept of Union citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I expressed my support for 2013 as European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with citizenship and of the Union, to assist citizens in fully exercising their right to free movement and residence within the territories of the Member States.
Mr. President, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and control of their effectiveness.
It is, indeed, necessary to find a proper balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level remains of considerable importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, particularly during times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
in accordance with its own objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses allocated to the Community budget is juxtaposed with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I Regulation undoubtedly represented one of the most effective acts.
of Union legislation, as it has laid the foundations for a European judicial space fostered and underpinned by legal certainty among European citizens.
The revision of this regulation addresses fundamental themes for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules concerning…
on the jurisdiction of disputes with parties domiciled in third countries and agreements concerning the choice of competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can guarantee more robust consumer protection, greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I have expressed my favorable vote.

Commissioner, today you have requested from Europe a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most stringent supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, even concerning the protection of employment, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely excess production capacity; it is a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now appears to be structural and concerns the destiny of the automobile itself, as a product in its current form.
We want to secure the automotive industry in Europe and want to avoid dispersing existing expertise, know-how, and professional skills.
We therefore request that a large-scale project of restructuring and revitalization be initiated, and that this be done expeditiously, as costs are proportional to time.
The restructuring cannot be merely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual enterprises.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing together the interested parties through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions, and the governments of individual countries, providing support through research, innovation, human capital development, reskilling, and the necessary funding.
I know that it will be an arduous undertaking because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive confrontation currently underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I believe that, in the end, it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective communal impetus and guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive global market.
The energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment, impacting thousands of precarious, yet also stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The largest steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a significant question regarding the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must reclaim the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs robust basic productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry; we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

And I believe that we must also move beyond a certain dualism that tonight hasn't been fully articulated here, but which is often heard in discussions on this sector—a dualism between environmentalists and workers—which is mistaken because it prevents us from seeing a perspective for the future.
An industry that views steelmaking as an integral part requires advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard diverse interests and needs.

Therefore, a robust planning effort is required, even at the European level, focused on sustainability—a principle on which, in my view, we must not regress—as a distinctive value-added element with which we aim to compete globally, supporting investment as has been stated.

Reported by various sources, new technologies, new processes for the requalification of plants for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also on the research of new and different materials.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. As we have recalled in this Assembly, next December the United Nations agency dedicated to communication and information technology will convene in Dubai for the World Telecommunications Conference.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We must not forget, and I am pleased with the words of Commissioner Tajani, the work that has been done to date, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed by another authority.

A supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states from around the world are members, many of whom are known to have issues related to democratic principles, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to consider the pillars of the Internet – freedom, participation, openness, innovation – to be at risk.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to safeguard the role of the internet and the role that, above all, the internet can play in revitalizing economic growth, but not only that, also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the goal of Europe and Dubai being united and speaking with a single voice.

Many controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications. In particular, those that foresee changes to Internet governance, which challenge network neutrality with detrimental consequences for consumers.
Therefore, the freedom of the internet is at risk, or more precisely, the freedom of expression and the protection of data.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to pry into not only the communications of its own citizens, but even the data transiting their networks.
The step from here to the restriction of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it contradicts the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Thank you, President. I have expressed my support for the colleague’s text. In particular, I concur with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in matters of jurisdiction for legal, judicial, and administrative authorities for legal professionals.
Furthermore, all sector initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of the Union founded on the rule of law.

Thank you, Mr. President. In recent years, the extraction of hydrocarbons, the so-called unconventional resources, including shale gas and shale oil, has driven an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to address this situation and be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore need to rely on its own potential reserves of gas and shale.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized shale gas exploration and are preparing for the extraction phase should a discovery allow it.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union, to ensure the effects of its
Undoubtedly valid from an economic standpoint, they do not create environmental problems due to the potential release of harmful substances into groundwater or the atmosphere.
Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that today's occasion should be used to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country with respect to the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undeniably an important economic and commercial component of the European Union.
It is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but that still needs to invest considerable effort to bring these processes to full fruition.

However, it is a country that, with this objective, continues to demonstrate its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that this is the task of the European Union to accompany them.

Therefore, I am certain that the signing of this strengthened agreement will allow for advancements, as its approval will reinforce an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent support from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and this is something I believe should have been emphasized even more in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that progress toward democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and reciprocal commitment to open and constructive dialogue.

Our objective should not be to adopt a negative stance towards these and other countries in the face of the immediate implementation of changes. Our objective should be to support the effort of these countries to achieve the goal of respecting human rights principles as well.

Madam Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to thank the speakers for the reports we will vote on tomorrow. Just a brief passage on the stripping of [assets/rights] and I concur with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
But I wanted to dwell on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera relationship which I greet and with whom I offer my congratulations.

I wanted to say something—with the previous common fisheries policy, we contributed only to increasing the distance between the institutions that regulate fishing and its actors, namely the fishermen.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003, in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal that aims to eliminate even the exemption from the prohibition of removing shark fins onboard Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further guaranteeing sharks the protection they require, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
